task_name: Metadiscourse Classification Task: Functional Alignment Matrix Analysis
objective: Classify highlighted expressions in the column 'expression' using the Functional Alignment Matrix framework that distinguishes F1 (Lexico-syntactic Function) from F2 (Contextual Function). Classification applies to the highlighted expression within its discourse context.
important_note: Only consider the whole expression inside the 'expression' column.

core_principle.definition: Metadiscourse is distinct from propositional aspects of discourse. Metadiscourse refers to the writer's rhetorical acts within the discourse, denoting writer-reader interaction.
core_principle.key_insight: The same linguistic form can function differently depending on both its lexico-syntactic structure (F1) and its contextual role (F2). Alignment or misalignment between these two dimensions determines the final classification.
core_principle.hyland_integration: Once metadiscourse is confirmed through F1×F2 analysis, Hyland's Framework describes how it is realized as Interactive or Interactional (with specific subcategories and markers).

f1_lexico_syntactic_local_function.name: F1: Lexico-syntactic + Local Context Function
f1_lexico_syntactic_local_function.description: Function determined by the form's structural, syntactic, and local contextual properties within the immediate sentence. Local context is defined as the linguistic environment bounded by sentence markers (period, question mark, exclamation mark, or major semicolon). Includes morphological patterns, syntactic positioning, intra-sentential collocations, and conventional phrasal patterns, but excludes discourse-level contextual factors beyond the sentence boundary.
f1_lexico_syntactic_local_function.scope: Analysis restricted to the immediate sentence containing the target expression
f1_lexico_syntactic_local_function.boundary: Orthographic sentence boundaries (. ? ! ; as major breaks)

types.label: Metadiscourse at Lexico-syntactic Level
types.definition: Fully non-propositional forms that convey stance, engagement, or attitude, without carrying core propositional content
types.identification: Based on syntactic/structural cues and morphological patterns

types.label: Propositional at Lexico-syntactic Level
types.definition: Forms that structurally carry factual or referential content
types.identification: Integrated into clause structure, descriptive function, no stance markers

f2_global_contextual_function.name: F2: Global Contextual Function
f2_global_contextual_function.description: Actual function determined by discourse elements beyond the immediate sentence, including preceding and following sentences, paragraph/section structure, genre conventions, rhetorical situation, and overall discourse goals. Global context encompasses all factors external to the sentence containing the target expression.
f2_global_contextual_function.scope: Analysis of inter-sentential relationships and broader discourse organization
f2_global_contextual_function.boundary: Beyond the immediate sentence; includes all supra-sentential discourse factors

types.label: Metadiscourse at Contextual Level
types.definition: Organizes text, guides reader, manages writer-reader interaction, or expresses stance/evaluation in the specific discourse context

types.label: Propositional at Contextual Level
types.definition: Contributes factual meaning, describes states of affairs, or adds referential content in the larger discourse

context_boundaries.definition: Clear operational distinction between local and global context

local_context.definition: The immediate sentence containing the target expression
includes: All words, phrases, and clauses within the same sentence
Syntactic structure and word order within the sentence
Punctuation internal to the sentence (commas, dashes, colons)

global_context.definition: All discourse elements beyond the immediate sentence
includes: Genre conventions (PhD thesis, research article, etc.)
Writer-reader relationship in the broader discourse

context_boundaries.rationale: Sentence boundaries provide a clear, operationalizable distinction that annotators can consistently apply, while allowing for both structural/local pattern analysis (F1) and broader discourse function analysis (F2).

functional_alignment_matrix.description: Four possible classification outcomes based on F1 × F2 alignment

classifications.description: Both lexico-syntactically and contextually align as metadiscourse
classifications.example: Clearly, this demonstrates… (sentence-initial attitudinal adverb with comma, functioning rhetorically in context)

classifications.description: Form appears metadiscursive, but contributes factual meaning in the larger discourse
classifications.example: I believe this effect occurs at high temperature (hedging verb structure, but 'believe' reports content of a belief, not writer's stance)

classifications.description: Form is propositional, but context shows rhetorical or evaluative use
classifications.example: The data show that… (propositional form used as authorial stance marker in argumentative context)

classifications.description: Fully factual and referential across both levels
classifications.example: The samples were heated to 90°C (bare assertion with no stance or rhetorical function)

f1_lexico_syntactic_indicators.description: Syntactic and structural cues for identifying F1 classification

md_f1_indicators.description: Structural patterns that signal metadiscourse at the lexico-syntactic level

lexical_features.description: Lexical and phrasal patterns detectable within the sentence boundary

patterns.description: Conventional patterns indicating text-internal reference detectable at local level

types.detection: Proximal demonstrative ('this'/'these') + genre-naming noun signals self-reference through local collocation pattern
types.note: Distal demonstratives ('that'/'those') typically indicate external reference

types.detection: First-person pronoun + verb naming textual/rhetorical act
Deictic reference to text location combined with text-act verb
Possessive or demonstrative + noun naming discourse element
types.f1_classification: Context-dependent (requires F2 analysis to determine if self-referential)

patterns.description: Conventional metadiscourse patterns formed by pronoun-verb collocations
Fixed or semi-fixed expressions functioning as metadiscourse units

subcategories.instance: hostage-takers seem to have sought out…

subcategories.example: It seems that X…, It appears that…

categories.note: Classification depends on syntactic positioning and addressee

subcategories.condition: When directed at third party, expressing writer's attitude toward desirability of actions
When addressing reader directly or indirectly

categories.function: Signals author stance or reinforces claim, without adding propositional content

categories.definition: Parenthetical remarks that serve as temporary departure from main topic to convey special message to readers
categories.example: Higher-paid (but by no means highly paid) local authority employees... may strike
categories.condition: Only when engaging reader's judgment, not when adding propositional information

categories.example: I believe this study is full of complexities
categories.function: Makes entire phrase attitudinal, expressing writer's attitude toward state of affairs

categories.condition: Only when syntactic cues (commas) separate them from main clause, or used to answer rhetorical question
categories.example_md: Usually, it means several new emails... (comma separation)

categories.note: When fronted and set off by commas, function metadiscursively

examples: It is, of course, difficult to measure.
The results are, in a sense, inconclusive.

categories.description: Propositional form (I think, I believe) gets syntactically detached and functions as metadiscourse
examples: It is important — I think — to notice this.
The problem, I believe, lies elsewhere.

categories.description: Structurally clause-like, but functioning metadiscursively to frame what follows

categories.condition: Only when used to indicate hypothetical situation on part of writer
categories.function: Presents claim as one possibility among many, expressing opinion without full commitment
categories.example: ...a Labour government can sometimes get away with announcing policies which, had they come from the mouth of a conservative minister, would have provoked howls of anger

p_f1_indicators.description: Structural patterns that signal propositional function at the lexico-syntactic level

categories.function: Propositional when embedded in clause reporting others' opinions rather than expressing writer's stance
categories.example: For those who believe that anything but prison is a soft option… (attribute belief, not author's stance)

categories.function: Propositional when indicating agency in factual reporting only
categories.example: I measured the samples (conveys action, not stance)

categories.function: Propositional when sharpening or specifying factual content rather than indicating commitment

categories.condition: When used to give extra information about the topic
categories.example: The CEO (who was appointed last year) announced the merger

categories.pattern: Declaratives without modal or stance markers
categories.function: Purely propositional, presenting information as fact
categories.example: The results indicate an increase in X

categories.function: Propositional when describing physical or logical ability, not epistemic possibility
categories.example: The machine can produce 100 units per hour

categories.condition: Not counted as metadiscourse due to propositional nature in default usage
categories.example: The machine usually works (integrated into clause, describes typical behavior)

f2_contextual_tests.description: Apply these tests sequentially to determine F2 classification. Context must be checked (Hyland, 2017).

core_tests.instruction: Remove the candidate item from the sentence
core_tests.question: Does the core propositional meaning change?

example.sentence: I believe this effect occurs at high temperature
example.result: This effect occurs at high temperature
example.analysis: Propositional meaning UNCHANGED (still about the effect)

core_tests.instruction: Identify the primary function of the item in context
questions: Does it describe a state of affairs in the world?

core_tests.instruction: Examine the surrounding discourse (context before and after, section, discipline)
core_tests.question: Does the item's function change based on what comes before/after?

examples.expression: The data show that X is true
As the data show, we can conclude Y
examples.context: Used as stance marker in argument

core_tests.question: Can it be replaced by purely propositional alternatives?

decision_logic.metadiscourse: Cannot substitute without losing rhetorical function

contextual_features_checklist.description: Additional contextual factors that influence F2 classification

rhetorical_situation.rule: Same lexical item may function differently across contexts (e.g., 'should' in methods vs. discussion)

questions: Is the item guiding the reader through text organization?
Is it expressing writer's commitment to proposition?
Is it establishing common ground with reader?
Is the item part of a factual claim about the world?
Is it contributing to the truth conditions of the statement?
Is it describing an action, state, or event?
Is it essential to the referential meaning?

hyland_taxonomy_reference.description: After confirming metadiscourse through F1×F2 analysis, use Hyland's Framework to identify specific subcategory
hyland_taxonomy_reference.note: This taxonomy provides the specific metadiscourse categories for classification once metadiscourse function is established

interactive_metadiscourse.definition: Resources that help organize discourse and guide the reader through the text

categories.function: Express relations (additive, causative, contrastive) between main clauses
Signal text boundaries or elements of schematic text structure
Refer to information in other parts of the text
Reference to information from other texts
Explain or reformulate information to ensure comprehension

interactional_metadiscourse.definition: Resources that involve the reader in the discourse and express the writer's stance

categories.function: Indicate uncertainty or open up dialogue; mitigate commitment to a proposition
Emphasize certainty, close down alternatives, express certainty
Indicate writer's affective attitude to propositions

classification_workflow.description: Step-by-step process for applying the Functional Alignment Matrix

steps.name: Analyze F1 (Lexico-syntactic Function)
steps.description: Examine the structural and syntactic properties of the expression
actions: Identify syntactic positioning (sentence-initial, parenthetical, integrated, tag)
Check for punctuation cues (commas, dashes, parentheses)
Determine morphological pattern (verb forms, modal auxiliaries, etc.)
Match against F1 indicators in framework

steps.name: Analyze F2 (Contextual Function)
steps.description: Apply contextual tests to determine actual discourse function

steps.name: Determine Classification
steps.description: Combine F1 and F2 to determine final classification

steps.name: Identify Hyland Category (if metadiscourse)
steps.description: If classification is Stable Metadiscourse or Contextual Shift to Metadiscourse, identify the specific Hyland category
actions: Match against Interactive or Interactional categories
Identify specific subcategory (hedge, booster, attitude marker, etc.)
steps.output: Specific Hyland metadiscourse category or 'N/A' if propositional

steps.name: Evidence Documentation
required_elements: F2 analysis with contextual test results

output_format.description: For each highlighted expression, provide this JSON structure:

f1_lexico_syntactic.description: Metadiscourse or Propositional at lexico-syntactic level

f1_evidence.description: Syntactic position, punctuation, structural pattern supporting F1 classification

f2_contextual.description: Metadiscourse or Propositional at contextual level

f2_tests_applied.description: Results from each contextual test applied

hyland_category.description: Specific Hyland category if metadiscourse; 'N/A' if propositional

hyland_subcategory.description: Specific subcategory (hedge, booster, transition, etc.) if applicable

justification.description: Comprehensive rationale explaining F1 analysis, F2 analysis, and alignment

contextual_factors.description: Contextual factors that influenced F2 classification

note.description: Additional observations, borderline considerations, or alternative interpretations

example_stable_metadiscourse.f1_evidence: Sentence-initial attitudinal adverb 'Clearly' with comma separation, giving scope over entire proposition

f2_tests_applied.result: Removing 'Clearly,' does not change propositional content—only removes epistemic stance
Expresses writer's certainty/attitude toward the proposition

example_stable_metadiscourse.justification: F1 Analysis: 'Clearly' is structurally positioned as a sentence-initial attitudinal adverb, separated by comma, which is a canonical MD-F1 pattern. F2 Analysis: Contextually, it functions to express the writer's epistemic certainty and does not contribute propositional content about the subject matter. The removal test confirms this—removing 'Clearly' leaves the propositional meaning intact. Classification: Both F1 and F2 align as metadiscourse, resulting in Stable Metadiscourse. This functions as a booster in Hyland's framework.

contextual_factors.co_text_influence: Used to strengthen author's interpretation of results

example_stable_metadiscourse.note: Unambiguous classification with strong alignment across both dimensions

example_contextual_shift_to_proposition.f1_evidence: Hedging verb 'believe' in 'I believe' construction—typical MD-F1 pattern

f2_tests_applied.result: Removing 'I believe' changes meaning—the sentence is about the content of a belief
Describes a state of affairs (what is believed) rather than expressing writer's stance
Context shows this reports belief content, not authorial hedging

example_contextual_shift_to_proposition.justification: F1 Analysis: 'I believe' structurally matches the hedging verb pattern (first-person pronoun + attitudinal verb), typically signaling MD-F1. F2 Analysis: However, contextual analysis reveals the expression contributes factual content about what is believed ('this effect occurs at high temperature') rather than hedging the writer's commitment. The removal test shows propositional meaning would change. Classification: F1 suggests metadiscourse, but F2 reveals propositional function—a Contextual Shift to Proposition. This is NOT Hyland's metadiscourse in context.

contextual_factors.co_text_influence: Reporting the content of others' beliefs, not expressing writer's hedged stance

example_contextual_shift_to_proposition.note: This illustrates the importance of contextual analysis—form alone is insufficient for classification

example_contextual_shift_to_metadiscours.f1_evidence: Propositional verb form 'show' in declarative construction 'The data show that...'

f2_tests_applied.result: Functions as authorial stance marker, not purely evidential reporting
In argumentative context, used to strengthen writer's position rhetorically
Cannot substitute with neutral reporting verb without losing rhetorical force

example_contextual_shift_to_metadiscours.justification: F1 Analysis: 'The data show' is structurally a propositional form—declarative verb with subject. F2 Analysis: Contextually, in the discussion section's argumentative context, this functions as a stance marker. The writer uses 'show' (rather than neutral 'indicate') to strengthen their interpretive claim. Co-text reveals this is not objective reporting but rhetorical positioning. Classification: F1 is propositional, but F2 reveals metadiscursive function—a Contextual Shift to Metadiscourse. Functions as evidential with clear stance-taking.

contextual_factors.co_text_influence: Preceded by author's interpretation, followed by evaluative claims

example_contextual_shift_to_metadiscours.note: Shows how propositional forms can function metadiscursively depending on rhetorical situation

example_stable_proposition.f1_evidence: Bare declarative assertion, passive voice, factual reporting without stance markers

f2_tests_applied.result: Describes action/state of affairs in the research procedure

example_stable_proposition.justification: F1 Analysis: Structurally a bare assertion with no modal, stance, or rhetorical markers. F2 Analysis: Contextually reports factual procedure in methods section. No discourse organization, stance expression, or reader engagement function. Classification: Both F1 and F2 align as propositional—Stable Proposition. This is purely referential content, not metadiscourse.
example_stable_proposition.note: Unambiguous propositional classification at both levels

confidence_scale.5: Unambiguous alignment between F1 and F2 with clear evidence
confidence_scale.4: Strong F1 and F2 evidence with minor interpretive considerations
confidence_scale.3: Moderate confidence; some ambiguity in F1 or F2 classification
confidence_scale.2: Low confidence; significant uncertainty in contextual analysis
confidence_scale.1: Minimal confidence; classification highly uncertain or borderline

critical_checkpoints: F1: Expression analyzed within sentence boundary? (Local context defined)
F1: Syntactic positioning verified? (Initial, parenthetical, integrated, tag)
F1: Punctuation cues identified within sentence? (Commas, dashes, parentheses)
F1: Morphological and phrasal patterns matched to framework?
F1: Self-referential patterns detected at local level? (e.g., 'this + genre-name')
F1: Conventional collocations indicating metadiscourse identified?
F2: Global context analyzed beyond sentence boundary?
F2: All relevant contextual tests applied at discourse level?
F2: Rhetorical situation considered? (Genre, section, purpose)
Boundary: Clear distinction maintained between local (sentence) and global (discourse) analysis?
Alignment: F1×F2 relationship clearly explained with reference to both local and global factors?
Hyland: Correct category assigned if metadiscourse confirmed?
consistency_principles: Local context is defined operationally as the immediate sentence; global context includes all discourse elements beyond the sentence boundary
F1 classification must be justified with evidence from within the target sentence
F2 classification must reference factors beyond the immediate sentence (preceding/following text, section, genre, etc.)
Self-referential patterns detectable within sentence boundaries (e.g., 'this thesis') should be classified as MD-F1
Similar lexico-syntactic structures in identical syntactic positions should receive equivalent F1 classifications
Same expression in different contexts may have different F2 classifications
F1 classification precedes F2 analysis—analyze structure before context
Evidence-based reasoning: Every classification must cite specific F1 indicators and F2 test results
Alignment explanation required: Always explain how/why F1 and F2 align or diverge

key_reminders: F1 includes LOCAL context (the immediate sentence); F2 includes GLOBAL context (beyond the sentence boundary)
Local context boundary: The sentence containing the target expression, marked by orthographic sentence boundaries
Global context includes: All sentences beyond the target sentence, plus genre, section, and rhetorical factors
Self-referential patterns like 'this + genre-name' are detectable at F1 through local collocation analysis
F1 question: What does the form + immediate sentence signal? F2 question: What does it accomplish in the broader discourse?
Sentence boundaries provide a clear, operationalizable distinction between F1 and F2 analysis
F1 analyzes STRUCTURE; F2 analyzes CONTEXT—these are separate dimensions
Alignment ≠ Agreement: F1 and F2 can diverge (contextual shifts)
Punctuation is crucial for F1: Commas, dashes, parentheses signal detachment
Context is mandatory for F2: Always apply contextual tests systematically
Form does not determine function: MD-F1 structures can have P-F2 function
Hyland's taxonomy applies AFTER confirming metadiscourse through F1×F2 analysis
Same lexical item, different functions: 'First' in methods vs. introduction
Confidence reflects both F1 and F2 certainty: Lower confidence if either dimension is ambiguous

theoretical_notes.core_insight: This framework recognizes that linguistic forms have both inherent structural properties (F1) and context-dependent discourse functions (F2). Metadiscourse identification requires alignment analysis across both dimensions.
theoretical_notes.hyland_compatibility: Hyland's taxonomy describes metadiscourse categories. This framework provides the analytical apparatus to determine when expressions function as metadiscourse through F1×F2 analysis.
theoretical_notes.key_innovation: By separating lexico-syntactic function (F1) from contextual function (F2), the framework can systematically identify: (1) Stable classifications where form and function align, and (2) Contextual shifts where form and function diverge.
